messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Hey Ken,                   Send me your mailing address and let me how much lobster you d like me to send, LOL. Already got lots of contacts
messages.messageBody:
Hey Ken,
                  Send me your mailing address and let me how much lobster
you'd like me to send, LOL.
Already got lots of contacts to sell me garbage.
Have a great New Years Eve.
 
Mark
 
 

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Kenneth Wilson
Sent: Friday, December 23, 2005 1:14 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?


Mark,

I don't travel, just send me the lobster and bear
eh?!!  I'm sure you can always find someone to sell
you stuff... Good and Bad.

Milt, I forgot....you must follow the most important
rule...."Don't get high on your own supply"!!!!.....I
thought you weren't from this world.  Off to the
in-laws.............

Merry commercialism.

Ken

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Of course I meant you Andres! Jets or Giants?!  LOL!!  Even better, not as far to come.  You ll still have to get a passport so you can travel to hostile
messages.messageBody:
Of course I meant you Andres!
Jets or Giants?!� LOL!!� Even better, not as far to come.� You'll still have
to get a passport so you can travel to hostile evil empire of Canada. Bay of
Fundy is in my backyard so we can go kayaking.
I'll pick you up in St. Stephen when you cross over from Calais. August and
September are the best months here.�All you need to bring is your Nihonto
knowledge.
�
Talk to you soon. Have a great New Years Eve.
�
Mark
P.S. Say hello to Dick Clark for me
�

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On

To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

Mark,

If the Andres you refer to is me, I'm as New Yorker as they come, not
international at all. I work in Manhattan and live in the Poconos. :)

Beer and lobster sounds great. Just pick a date... I've always meant
to go take a look at New Brunswick, especially Fundy Bay. Heard good
stuff about it.

If you didn't mean me, then too late, I'm still going.

Dewa,

Andres

messages.subject: Re: Where do you buy your Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: ... Since no one wish anyone a happy Hanukkah, I assume you are all gentiles. Only gentiles pay retail.............. happy Hanukkah, may your candles last more
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "nihontochicken" <rick@s...> wrote:
>
> --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Kenneth Wilson <kdw21620@y...>
wrote:
> > Milt keeps on trying to sell me stuff at full retail when I
> > know he got them cheap, plus I am originally from NY and we
> > don't pay retail!
>
>

Since no one wish anyone a happy Hanukkah, I assume you are all
gentiles.
Only gentiles pay retail..............

happy Hanukkah, may your candles last more than 8 days.

p.s. I wished everyone a merry Christmas and a happy New year, plus
happy Kwanzaa so I won't nag again...... stay safe, stay sober ( stay
away from the dry red ) , don't slip on the ice AND watch out for that
falling icicles !!

Milt

messages.subject: Re: Where do you buy your Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: ... Hahahahaha!!!  Reminds me of a trip to NY City many moons ago when I was driving my little Honda Civic through downtown Manhattan, dodging all the Checker

> Milt keeps on trying to sell me stuff at full retail when I
> know he got them cheap, plus I am originally from NY and we
> don't pay retail!

Hahahahaha!!! Reminds me of a trip to NY City many moons ago when I
was driving my little Honda Civic through downtown Manhattan, dodging
all the Checker cabs (built like tanks, and they were all dented!),
listening to the radio, and heard, "This is station KNYC, 1500 on your
radio dial, but for you, 1498."

NC ;o)

And with that shaggy dog story, here's wishing all here a Merry Xmas,
or, if preferred, a more PC Happy Holidaze!

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Milt & info about NY shinsa
messages.msgSnippet: Pent up aggression, must payback year s worth of cheap insults and bug insults.  I kid because I love.  Also since attempts to get mantis stuff cheaply in
messages.messageBody:
Pent up aggression, must payback year's worth of cheap
insults and bug insults. I kid because I love. Also
since attempts to get mantis stuff cheaply in private
have failed, so I figure public badgering and insults
are next move.

Wish I could meet you all in Tampa. One day I will
make a show! As rumors to another shinsa in NY, will
it be just shinsa or is there a chance at a show? For
those that went, what was it like last time, were
there any buying/trading opportunities? People
networking etc? When I moved to Maryland, I thought I
would be able to make NY shows (I'm from there). Of
course they stopped having them the year I got close.
At least I have a token kai to go to 1hr 45 mins away
now even if it kills me.

Thanks.
Ken

messages.msgSnippet: My Dear Milton; You should know about crappy tsuba. You have cornered the market and made a study of them over the past 5 years. Isn t it time you moved onto
messages.messageBody:
My Dear Milton;

You should know about crappy tsuba.
You have cornered the market and made a study of them over the past 5 years.

Isn't it time you moved onto at least mediocre tsuba and fittings?

Even the Ferengi appreciate beauty, even if it is at the most basic level.

Have a Merry Christmas,

John

at least i have a fair chance to get my $ back or even make 10 bucks
or so when I get tired of some of them.

Milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Mark; No we have monthly meetings at the Vancouver Museum board room, second Tuesday of every month if you are in the neighborhood. Long way to come for a
messages.messageBody:
Hi Mark;

No we have monthly meetings at the Vancouver Museum board room, second
Tuesday of every month if you are in the neighborhood.

Long way to come for a meeting LOL.

John


----- Original Message -----
From: "Mark Jaillet" <mjaillet@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, December 23, 2005 7:16 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?


> Thanks John,
> Does your study correspond by e-mail also or is it strickly
> in person? I was in Tofino for the first time two years ago and I loved
> it!
> Mountains, water and NO BUGS! Truely God's country. I'm basically looking
> for opportunities to at least "see" Nihonto products. Are there merchants
> of
> Nihonto related products in Canada? I'm aware of Darcy Brockbank. Great
> stuff but very high end. I'm looking to find "entrance level" stuff. I've
> even gone from looking for Katana's to Tsuba's. Are there sellers on Ebay
> that have good reputations? Does Vancouver have a good supply of sellers?
> Any annual shows? Sorry for sounding desperate! LOL! But I don't in a
> Nihonto rich enviroment!
>
> Great talking to you John.
>
> Mark
>
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of John Berta
> Sent: Friday, December 23, 2005 10:47 AM

>
>
> Hi Mark;
>
> Well unfortunately I am on the other cost, in Vancouver, no lobsters here
> just Dungeness and snow crabs on this side.
>
> I do not know of any study groups in the Maritimes but Toronto has a
> couple
> and Montreal has a few people into nihonto and armour. We have a good
> group
> in Vancouver if you are ever out here getting lost on our hills.
>
> I wish you a Merry Christmas, and if you do not have a study group create
> one, all you need is one other person to start, and your on your way.
>
> John
>
>

messages.msgSnippet: Mark, I don t travel, just send me the lobster and bear eh?!!  I m sure you can always find someone to sell you stuff... Good and Bad. Milt, I forgot....you
messages.messageBody:
Mark,

I don't travel, just send me the lobster and bear
eh?!! I'm sure you can always find someone to sell
you stuff... Good and Bad.

Milt, I forgot....you must follow the most important
rule...."Don't get high on your own supply"!!!!.....I
thought you weren't from this world. Off to the
in-laws.............

Merry commercialism.

Ken

messages.messageBody:
Mark,

If the Andres you refer to is me, I'm as New Yorker as they come, not
international at all. I work in Manhattan and live in the Poconos. :)

Beer and lobster sounds great. Just pick a date... I've always meant
to go take a look at New Brunswick, especially Fundy Bay. Heard good
stuff about it.

If you didn't mean me, then too late, I'm still going.

Dewa,

Andres

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks John, Does your study correspond by e-mail also or is it strickly in person? I was in Tofino for the first time two years ago and I loved it! Mountains,
messages.messageBody:
Thanks John,
Does your study correspond by e-mail also or is it strickly
in person? I was in Tofino for the first time two years ago and I loved it!
Mountains, water and NO BUGS! Truely God's country. I'm basically looking
for opportunities to at least "see" Nihonto products. Are there merchants of
Nihonto related products in Canada? I'm aware of Darcy Brockbank. Great
stuff but very high end. I'm looking to find "entrance level" stuff. I've
even gone from looking for Katana's to Tsuba's. Are there sellers on Ebay
that have good reputations? Does Vancouver have a good supply of sellers?
Any annual shows? Sorry for sounding desperate! LOL! But I don't in a
Nihonto rich enviroment!

Great talking to you John.

Mark


-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
[mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of John Berta
Sent: Friday, December 23, 2005 10:47 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?


Hi Mark;

Well unfortunately I am on the other cost, in Vancouver, no lobsters here
just Dungeness and snow crabs on this side.

I do not know of any study groups in the Maritimes but Toronto has a couple
and Montreal has a few people into nihonto and armour. We have a good group
in Vancouver if you are ever out here getting lost on our hills.

I wish you a Merry Christmas, and if you do not have a study group create
one, all you need is one other person to start, and your on your way.

John

> Have a great holiday season everyone. It's been great listening to your

>
> Mark

messages.msgSnippet: Hi Mark; Well unfortunately I am on the other cost, in Vancouver, no lobsters here just Dungeness and snow crabs on this side. I do not know of any study
messages.messageBody:
Hi Mark;

Well unfortunately I am on the other cost, in Vancouver, no lobsters here
just Dungeness and snow crabs on this side.

I do not know of any study groups in the Maritimes but Toronto has a couple
and Montreal has a few people into nihonto and armour. We have a good group
in Vancouver if you are ever out here getting lost on our hills.

I wish you a Merry Christmas, and if you do not have a study group create
one, all you need is one other person to start, and your on your way.

John

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi John, Has Christmas come early?!  I could have sworn it was only friday! You re telling me you know of contacts in Canada for study and collection? Well
messages.messageBody:
Hi John,
Has Christmas come early?! I could have sworn it was only
friday!
You're telling me you know of contacts in Canada for study and collection?
Well Merry Christmas to me! LOL
I live in New Brunswick on the east coast. Occasionally I'll make it out
west to do some mountain climbing and I've been down to New Hampshire, Mount
Washington. Apart from that, I usually don't get state side. I can just see
myself trying to explain to a customs officer that I'm travelling to the
U.S. to attend a Japanese Sword Show! LOL! I'm going to need a passport next
year just to cross the border into Maine so I can buy cheap milk!
Where abouts are you located John?
Any information you can provide me with would be greatly appreciated. If
anyone out there in Nihonto land wants to come to New Brunswick and share
their knowledge, I will supply Beer and Lobsters.
Now if there's going to be more than 10 of you or any international
arrivals, (Andres), I will need some time to plan.
Have a great holiday season everyone. It's been great listening to your
banter.

Mark


-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
[mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of John Berta
Sent: Thursday, December 22, 2005 5:53 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?


Hi Mark;

Where in Canada are you. There are some very good study groups in Canada
and opportunity to learn and collect swords and fittings.

John
----- Original Message -----
From: "Mark Jaillet" <mjaillet@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, December 22, 2005 12:22 PM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?


Hi Ron,
Anthony should try collecting up here in Canada! Now THAT
is a challenge. I for one would be more than interested to know what you
have to offer and suggestions would be more than appreciated. I'd be more
than happy to [ay in "lobster" or "hockey skates"! LOL!!!!

Kind regards, Mark



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Ron Hartmann
Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 10:04 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?


Anthony -

Sorry to sound like such a "merchant" but if you're interested I can send
you some pictures of a very nice selection of good quality iron tsuba that
I'm selling. Most are $200 range, more or less. If you are new at this I
would be happy to recommend good ones that would help teach you about these
things. Some of these have been to a number of shows and are now kept home
so that I can keep my table at the shows, fresh. All are authentic, for
sure. The shows seem to have a wonderful selection of nice quality tsuba
these days and that is good for the buyer, bad for the seller since there is
such a "selection" to pick from. Anyway...just thought I'd toss this idea
out to you. I've been around for going on 40 years...gosh, that's a little
frightening to put in writing!

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: anwahi
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 4:23 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?


Hello,

I'm new here and to collecting Tsuba. Where do you buy your Tsuba from?
I know there's several websites you can find with a Google search, an
occasional Token Kai show like the one in SF, or Ebay (most look like
junk). I'm looking for good sources of authentic Tsuba. Obviously the
only way to be really sure of authenticity is to purchase papered
Tsuba, but because I'm starting off I want some sources of authentic
Tsuba more reasonably priced. Any suggestions?

Thanks for your helpo in advance,
Anthony

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Anthony- For 2006 we have decided that our meetings will fall on the third Sunday of each month, thus to avoid lots of holidays, playoffs, bowl games and such.
messages.messageBody:
Anthony-
For 2006 we have decided that our meetings will fall on the third
Sunday of each month, thus to avoid lots of holidays, playoffs, bowl
games and such. We will be there on the 15th, discussing anything
with the character "ONE" in it; Mori family mon, Ichinotani kabuto,
Sadakazu, Korekazu, Ichimai-boshi and mayhaps an Ichimonji katana or
two.
There isn't much good I can say publicly about the SF Japanese Sword
Society, I would give them a look if you wish but wouldn't give them
any of your money or your items to handle until you know more about
them and us. Meetings start just after noon, hope you will join us.
Feel free to email me off list with questions...
-t

Anthony

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Anthony, Stay away from mantis!  Actually, I think you should do as David said and invest in a book or 2.  It is personal, what you like is what you like-
messages.messageBody:
Anthony,

Stay away from mantis! Actually, I think you should
do as David said and invest in a book or 2. It is
personal, what you like is what you like- collect
that. There are many collections out there- same
school, similiar design, certain periods of time,
types of construction, and so on and so on. I would
also agree profit should not be the motivating factor,
too many guys will tell you their stories of losses.

For me I had a connection with the mantis and built my
collection around that motif. I like finding the
renditions of the bug from the various schools and
time periods. It also helps me sort through the many
available items for sale. That is my personal taste.
Milt I think took his love of hawk paintings and that
transferred over into his tsuba collection, although,
he doesn't stick to just that motif.

Gain some basic knowledge 1st. It will help you to
avoid buying mistakes and also help you put together a
better collection if that is your desire.

One of the nice things about fittings is that you
don't have to spend thousands to get something decent.
However, you can spend $40,000 if you want/can. I am
impressed with their artistic qualities. I don't have
a mentor really and I haven't handled as much as I
would like, but I am slowly learning. I would love to
sit down with someone more knowledgeable and be shown
iron quality. Jim G. said all it takes is handling a
few thousand tsuba.

Good luck.
Ken

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Kinko refers to soft metal work tsuba.  Sukashi refers to pierced tsuba. There are certainly no rules as to what designs are best to collect.  If you lack
messages.messageBody:
Kinko refers to soft metal work tsuba. Sukashi refers to pierced tsuba.

There are certainly no rules as to what designs are best to collect. If you lack opinions, you should collect books. I recommend starting with Sasano and Torigoye's books. You might want to own the Sukashi and Akasaka tusba Sano Museum catalogues as well. And it's nice to have the Haynes catalogues. Even just those books will represent a substantial investment, so think twice, before proceeding.

The only Nihonto material certain to hold its value and be easily resellable is very expensive top quality stuff. Top quality tsuba are not necessarily easily identified or defined, but pieces of the sort sell at auction at Christie's and Sotheby's for thousands of dollars. Not uncommonly for more than $5000.

David Zincavage
----- Original Message -----
From: Anthony H
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 10:50 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?


Ken,

Good info. Not sure whether to take it that this Kurt guy is a fraud or he has two inch thick glasses and can't tell the bugs apart.

Might be a simple question, but what is kinko or sukashi?

From reading what you said, is the Mantis design highly sought after or maybe you can tell what are the best designs are to collect? I'm sure a lot is personal tastes, but the question is more for what will hold value and easily be resold.

Thanks,
Anthony

Kenneth Wilson <kdw21620@...> wrote:
Anthony,

I also have purchased from Rich's sources (he is a
sukashi tsuba slut by the way). In addition I have
purchased from Ron. I would purchase from all of them
again. Many tsuba are not papered, it is not worth
the cost of many to put them through shinsa. Since it
is much harder to attribute to a particular smith, you
will also be likely to get a paper to a general school
(for the unsigned ones). There are all price points.

The only one I have not purchased from is that Kurt
Holtz dude. The major reason is that he tries to pass
off crickets as preying mantises. As if I don't know
the difference. Gets me all excited in searching ebay
and have a hit other than the Chen crappers and it
turns out to be a waste. Even mentions me by name,
like he couldn't just email me.

Be careful buying books, especially those japanese
ones. They are addicting in their own right and then
you end up with all these books you can't read. Of
course, if you can read them, I will tell you which
ones to buy and you can translate them for me.

Remember tsuba are 2 sided, if one sided don't buy or
if already purchased certainly don't email list that
you baught a 1 sided tsuba (I love to bring this
incident up makes me still laugh- happened to a list
member a few years ago). Milt can give you a
dissertation on how to buy on ebay. Tom Helm can also
tell you why those tsuba's recommended by Milt suck.
Actually I have gotten a few off ebay over the years
and prices are usually good. Just don't buy anything
from China, unless from a pilot living in Hong Kong
but he only cares about hizen (he gets touchy about
condemning all of china- basically don't buy from the
billion or so people minus one).

Ok, I put a lot of list history in this post and most
likely you have no idea of the stories behind them,
but I am reminiscing. Buy some books and find some
collectors to handle tsuba. Some like kinko some like
sukashi, some like both.

You can always ask questions here. Just remember
that any preying mantis themed tsuba and/or sword
fittings must be cheaply sold to me. Milt keeps on
trying to sell me stuff at full retail when I know he
got them cheap, plus I am originally from NY and we
don't pay retail! He complains about son's tuition at
BU and I keep telling him, I went to Grad school there
and they aren't getting anymore of my money. Have
fun!

all the best,
Ken aka "the mantis dude" a puveyor of all kamakiri
tosogou

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Anthony - Sorry to sound like such a merchant but if you re interested I can send you some pictures of a very nice selection of good quality iron tsuba that
messages.messageBody:
Anthony -

Sorry to sound like such a "merchant" but if you're interested I can send you some pictures of a very nice selection of good quality iron tsuba that I'm selling. Most are $200 range, more or less. If you are new at this I would be happy to recommend good ones that would help teach you about these things. Some of these have been to a number of shows and are now kept home so that I can keep my table at the shows, fresh. All are authentic, for sure. The shows seem to have a wonderful selection of nice quality tsuba these days and that is good for the buyer, bad for the seller since there is such a "selection" to pick from. Anyway...just thought I'd toss this idea out to you. I've been around for going on 40 years...gosh, that's a little frightening to put in writing!

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: anwahi
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 4:23 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?


Hello,

I'm new here and to collecting Tsuba. Where do you buy your Tsuba from?
I know there's several websites you can find with a Google search, an
occasional Token Kai show like the one in SF, or Ebay (most look like
junk). I'm looking for good sources of authentic Tsuba. Obviously the
only way to be really sure of authenticity is to purchase papered
Tsuba, but because I'm starting off I want some sources of authentic
Tsuba more reasonably priced. Any suggestions?

Thanks for your helpo in advance,
Anthony

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks to all who responded. The funny thing is I just came back from Japan last week. I spent 3 days in Kyoto and 4 in Tokyo. I wish I had known of some
messages.messageBody:
Thanks to all who responded.

The funny thing is I just came back from Japan last week. I spent 3 days in Kyoto and 4 in Tokyo. I wish I had known of some places to go to before I left. Oh, well that will only encourage me to go back to find these shops next time.

Thanks Again
Anthony
Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...> wrote:
Hi Anthony, and welcome to the list. I can personally recommend the
following dealers ( as I have has experience with them )

In the US.

Fred Wesiberg - http://www.nihonto.com/contents.html

Andrew Quirt - http://www.nihonto.us/

And in Japan

Seikeido ( they speak excellent english ) - http://www.seikeido.com/

Ginza Choshuya ( they speak excellent english ) -
http://world.choshuya.co.jp/

and the Fine Sword Company ( they also speak english ) -
http://www.finesword.co.jp/

All carry excellent tsuba and Fine Sword have a good cross range of
prices as well.

You idea is sound, stay away from Ebay unless you are very sure of
yourself and your knowledge. Jim Gilbert's site 9
http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/tsuba.htm ) has a good list of
tsuba books under the **Bibliography*
<http://home.earthlink.net/%7Ejggilbert/reading.htm>* link to chase down
as well. mmmm, for every 3 - 4 books I buy it seems, I miss a tsuba... :-)

Cheers

Richard

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Anthony, I don t think you need to buy papered tsuba to make sure they are authentic.  Just buy from reputable dealers. Perhaps the easiest way to learn
messages.messageBody:
Hi Anthony,

I don't think you need to buy papered tsuba to make sure they are authentic. Just buy from reputable dealers.

Perhaps the easiest way to learn about fittings is to buy as many books as you can and educate yourself - go to shows as well.

Good luck with your collecting!

Regards
